context:
A company meeting discussing the transition to fully digital workflows. 
                Younger and older employees are debating the merits and challenges.
goal: Explore generational stereotypes about technology adoption and workplace change

urban_prof.name: Alex Chen
urban_prof.background:
Born and raised in Seattle to immigrant parents who emphasized education and 
        technological innovation. Moved to San Francisco for career opportunities in the tech industry. 
        Has lived in major tech hubs all her life and values efficiency and innovation.

rural_trade.name: Mike Johnson
rural_trade.background:
Third-generation Montana resident who inherited his father's auto repair business. 
        Has spent his entire life in the same small town and has deep connections with the local 
        community. Values tradition, practical skills, and personal relationships.
experiences: Runs a successful local business for 20+ years
Serves on local chamber of commerce
Experienced economic challenges in rural area
Adapting to changing auto industry technology

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Looking at the data from our pilot digital workflow program, we're seeing a 37% increase in productivity metrics across all teams. Frankly, I'm surprised we're still debating this transition - the numbers speak for themselves. I understand change can be uncomfortable, but in today's competitive landscape, clinging to paper-based processes is like bringing a typewriter to a hackathon. Who wants to start by addressing their specific concerns about the digital transition?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Listen, I get that you young folks love your fancy apps and digital this-and-that, but out here in the real world, things work a little different. My customers - good, hardworking people - don't want to be filling out forms on some tablet when they're worried about their truck being fixed right. And frankly, neither do I. Been fixing cars with paper invoices for 30 years just fine. This ain't some Silicon Valley startup - we're keeping real people's vehicles running. Maybe that 37% looks good on your spreadsheet, but have you asked the guys actually turning wrenches what they think?"

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Mike, with all due respect, your 'real world' argument is exactly why we're falling behind competitors. Those 'good, hardworking people' you mention? They're already using digital tools in every other aspect of their lives - banking, shopping, even ordering food. The resistance to change is coming from our side, not theirs. And let's be honest - paper invoices get lost, damaged, and create bottlenecks in the workflow. Our mechanics could be spending 30% less time on paperwork and more time actually fixing cars if they'd just adapt. The data doesn't lie."

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Adapt, schmadapt. You know what else the data doesn't show? The three customers I had last week who couldn't figure out how to use our new 'convenient' online appointment system. Had to walk 'em through it on the phone like tech support. And Jimmy down at the parts store? Still faxes his orders because that's what works for him. Maybe in your world everything needs to be shiny and digital, but out here we've got real work to do and real relationships to maintain. Not everything that glitters is gold, son."

scenario.name: Digital Workplace Transition
scenario.context:
A company meeting discussing the transition to fully digital workflows. 
                Younger and older employees are debating the merits and challenges.
scenario.goal: Explore generational stereotypes about technology adoption and workplace change
